statement.tex: \text{If the function $f:\mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be defined by} \\ \text{$f(x)=2x-3$ and $g:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ by $g(x)=x^3+5$,} \\ \text{then find the value of $(f\circ g)^{-1}\left(x\right)$}.

step.context: %text What is $(f\circ g)\left(x\right)$ given that % \begin{align} f: \mathbb{R}\rightarrow \mathbb{R} &= 2x-3 \\ g: \mathbb{R}\rightarrow \mathbb{R} &= x^3+5 \end{align}
step.reason:
%text \underline{(f\circ g)\left(x \right)\text{ is shorthand for }f\left(g\left((x\right)\right)} And hence, %
\begin{align} f(x) &= 2x-3 \\ \implies (f\circ g)\left(x\right) &= f(g(x)) = 2(g(x))-3 \\ &= 2(x^3+5)-3 \\ &= 2x^3+10-3 \\ \implies (f\circ g)\left(x \right) &= 2x^3+7 \end{align}

step.context: %text If \[ y = (f\circ g)\left( x\right) = 2x^3 + 7\], then what is 'x' in terms of 'y'? And therefore, what is $(f\circ g)^{-1}\left(x\right)$? %
step.reason:
%text If $y = f(x)$, then $x = f^{-1}(y) \left[ \neq \dfrac{1}{f(y)} \right] $.
And hence,
%
\begin{align} y &= \overbrace{(f\circ g)\left( x\right) = 2x^3 + 7}^{\text{x is the independent variable}} \\ \implies x &= \underbrace{(f\circ g)^{-1}(y) = \sqrt[3]\dfrac{y-7}{2}} _{\text{y is the independent variable}} \end{align} \\
%text
But \underline\text{the convention} is to write the independent variable as x and the dependent variable as y.
And hence, \[ \qquad \qquad (f\circ g)^{-1}(y) = \sqrt[3]\dfrac{y-7}{2} \]
\underline\text{can be re-written as} \[ \qquad \qquad \underbrace{(f\circ g)^{-1}(x) = \sqrt[3]\dfrac{x-7}{2}}_{\text{By convention}}\]
